page.title: 12Papworth Hospital
page.content:
The original hospital was a sanatorium for the tuberculosis patients for whom the Settlement (see page 2) was developed. In the 1950s when TB was virtually eliminated the hospital ceased to be a sanatorium and was taken over by the National Health Service.
The Village Settlement devoted its energies to the handicapped and the hospital expanded and specialised. Today it is a world leader in the field of cardiac treatment, especially heart transplants. Although the hospital does treat other conditions, including chest problems and cancer, it does not have a casualty unit, and outpatient care is restricted to its special areas.
